BOX 3034 PEORIA, ILLINOIS 61614", which is also centered below it.::> <::attestation: Signature and Stamp Received, Stamped Signature: illegible (appears to be "Sweetners" and an illegible signature below) RECEIVED SEP 1 0 1971 T. J. ARMY A handwritten signature is present at the top, partially overlapping a horizontal line. Below the signature and line, there is a rectangular stamp with the word "RECEIVED" in bold, followed by the date "SEP 1 0 1971", and then "T. J. ARMY" at the bottom. All elements are centrally located.::> EXECUTIVE REPORTS # Miracle Fruit - MIRACLE FRUIT REPORT by Dr. G. E. Inglett. A special, limited report describing the unusual taste-modifying properties and commercial outlook of the fruit that causes sour foods to taste wonderfully sweet ( 20 pages). Price: $25 Sugar-Free Sweetener From Africa option SERENDIPITY BERRY REPORT by Dr. G. E. Inglett.: [ ] A completely revised report giving the details concerning the source of the world's sweetest substance ( 20 pages). Price: $19 option RECENT SWEETENER RESEARCH by Dr. G. E. Inglett.: [ ] A second reprinting of the second edition of the popular sweetener source booklet ( 38 pages). Price: $16 option PLANT PROTEIN USES IN THE DAIRY INDUSTRY by Dr. W. S. Claus.: [ ] Recent information on the increasing use of plant proteins in dairy products ( 18 pages). Price: $8 MAIL TO; NAME ORGANIZATION ADDRESS CITY STATE COUNTRY <::A photograph showing a cluster of small, dark, oval-shaped berries. The fruit of Dioscoreophyllum cum-minsii was initially named "serendipity" in our laboratory because of the unexpected finding of its intensely sweet properties. The berries are approximately 0.5 inch long. : figure::> <::A photograph showing two fruits, one whole and one cut in half to reveal a seed, placed on a grid background. Synsepalum dulcificum, miracle fruit, is native to tropical West Africa. The fruit is approximately 0.75 inch long. : figure::> Source: https://www.industrydocuments.ucsf.edu/docs/tjpv0228
